remove xfce and all that came with it
sudo aptitude purge libxfce\* libexo\*
which may not be precise. What you probably want is: sudo aptitude purge $(dpkg -l libxfce\* libexo\* |grep ^ii |awk '{ print $2 }')

you can iterate through the dependency list of xfce4 and remove them

I'm having interesting problems with my new logitech speakers, but it's not new, but I have isolated the problem, it appears that my speakers are crackling under linux, though while in my windows partition, they work fine. I am assuming it's screwy dell drivers, but what else do you think it could be/what should I do?

can you help with a sound issue? I know you work on alsa, my left audio crackles with my integrated SigmaTel... but it's not hardware becuase they work beautifully in Windows XP, so it must be some driver issue, can you help me? I posted the rest of my problem at http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?p=1258892
I'll look in a bit, kinda busy atm
ok, thanks, no problem
got some time now?
I'll ping you in ~5 mins
ok, kool
hi
hi!
ok, finally my left audio seems to be crackling in ubuntu, but I know it's not a hardware issue, because it works great in windows, so I'm figuring it's a driver/configureation problem
``amixer'' pastebinned?
one moment...
http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org/18117
so? also, windows reports I have a SigmaTel HIgh Def. Audio CODEC for integrated sound
I'll get to your pastebin in a sec
at what levels (and for which mixer elements) does the crackling become undetectable?
hmmmm... what file/song should I use to test?
any
I'm going to use gnome-volume-control to ajust ok?
sure
well, I guess it's kind of hard to determine... I have somany volumes to play with, everything in alsamixer/gnome-volume-control and my speaker volume
a good starting point is to set 'Front' and 'PCM' to 50%
then only adjust your speakers.
ok... PCM at 50%, front at 50% all else at 100%, speakers all the way up, still crackling
maybe it's the song....?
one moment
I'd say the crackling doesn't go away, it just gets lower as I lower my speaker volume
ok, then you'll need to try the various position_fix values.
where can I fill that in?
close everything using /dev/dsp* /dev/snd/*, modprobe -r snd-hda-intel && modprobe snd-hda-intel position_fix=1
repeat for values 2 and 3 if 1 doesn't work.
how can I find out what's using those devices?
just close all sound applications?
and, should I run modprobe as root?
modprobe requires privileged access, yes.
yes, you may need to log out of GNOME first.
logout, then back in?
or just kill the mixer applet, too
then run the commands? or run the commands first?
killall esd?
then modprobe -r && ...
no.
``lsof /dev/dsp* /dev/snd/*''
kk...
kill those processes, then modprobe -r  [..]
ok
I think it worked, will it stay like that when I reboot?!?!?!?
what worked?
sudo modprobe -r snd-hda-intel && sudo modprobe snd-hda-intel position_fix=1
no, it won't stick.
how can I make it stick?
you have to do this: echo 'options snd-hda-intel position_fix=1' |sudo tee -a /etc/modprobe.d/snd-hda-intel
ok, kool, thanks, I have to go now
I'll catch you later
I just rebooted, it's crackling again...
then posfix 1 wasn't appropriate. Keep going with 2.
but it worked, after I did it, but just when I rebooted it stopped working good
then unload it and pass the posfix parameter
right, but how can I get it to work for after I reboot
you can't if it doesn't work by default.
I got the setting to stick
well, does that card actually exist (i.e., driver for it loaded)?
I believe so, same one as before, that had the problems, I was trying a different one, but I took it out, and I guess some config got messed up
'I believe so' is much too querulous
well, the one in my computer is the hda intel one
``asoundconf list''
Names of available sound cards: Intel
and that's it?
yea
and you've used System> Preferences> Sound> Set default card ?
yea.
``asoundconf set-default-card Intel''
is there a way to restart alsa?
ah, all good after that last one
thank you once again :)
you there?
I'm in a meeting atm. What do you need?
nm then sorry to bother you
really... that's buggin me
what's up with getting the hda modules into ubuntu? or will that have to be in fiesty?
what's up with the hda modules and getting them into ubuntu?
too vague
did you feel like elaborating, or were you going to leave the question as vague?
I feel like being vauge... The newest alsa packages I mean, do you know if 1.0.13 is going to get into ubuntu edgy?
it's already in edgy.
really?
at least my portion of it is
you'll have to manually apply my queue, but yes, it all there. See kernel-team@
alsa-base is 10.0.11
so?
the available hda via kernel-team is post-1.0.13
what's kernel-team? Is it a repository?
so are there debs of a newer version of the driver with snd-hda-intel ?
I have to apply patches? will I have to configure the kernel, or just apply the patches and run, I have had experience with building a kernel... unsuccesful wifi support, but w/e
if you want nice debs of alsa-modules, just grab upstream's alsa-driver-1.0.13 and generate them using module-assistant
my patches are for our git repos, not for the end user
oh, I see, so where can I learn about making debs with m-a?
the README.Debian shipped with alsa-source
so what should I download off of alsa-project.org?
will I need the newest libasound for that?
ok, so unpackage the source, and look at the README.debian in debian/ ?
no, there's a README.Debian in alsa-source (binary package)
wait... you said to download alsa-driver
I meant what I typed. Download alsa-driver from upstream; consult the documentation from alsa-source.
I'm not sure.... so I can download alsa-driver from upstream, and just compile that, or get debian sid's and debuild that...?
do you want a short answer or a long answer?
but what is alsa-source? just a package in the repos?
I'm just very confused that's all, knowing what alsa-source is may clear things up
I understand alsa-driver is the driver

I use 'alsa-driver' to refer to the name of the Debian/Ubuntu source package that generates the alsa-base, linux-sound-base, and alsa-source binary packages. I use 'alsa-driver-1.0.13' when referring to upstream (ftp.alsa-project.org) alsa-driver tarball.
but mostly, the easiest thing may be just getting alsa-driver from debian sid, so I'll go with that
you mean alsa-source
sure
so just compile the alsa-source package? or that has to be added to my kernel in some way
read /usr/share/doc/alsa-source/README.Debian
wait... but the .orig.tar.gz of alsa-source _is_ alsa-driver
alsa-source is a binary package. It contains a stripped orig.tar.gz of alsa-driver-1.0.13.
but how do I get the source of it... I don't have it installed on my system at all, I'm sorry, I know I sound difficult, just install it, or download sid's deb?
wget http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/universe/a/alsa-driver/alsa-source_1.0.13-1ubuntu1_all.deb && sudo dpkg -i alsa-source_1.0.13-1ubuntu1_all.deb
thank you

the readme.debian says cd into the root of the headers or source tree that I have prepared and run make-kpkg, but should that be /usr/src/linux-headers-vers/ or /usr/src/linux-headers-vers-generic/ vers being 2.6.17-10
that's not in that readme, what would you do?
and that will build the deb of the driver, thank you
I got a: alsa-modules-2.6.17-10-generic depends on alsa-base (>= 1.0.12-1); however: Version of alsa-base on system is 1.0.11-5ubuntu1.
then grab feisty's alsa-base
and linux-sound-base
ok

feisty is the correct spelling.
feisty alsa-base is 1.0.11... grab upstream from alsa-project?

http://packages.ubuntu.com/feisty/sound/alsa-base

i.e., play 'spot the feisty packages' at http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/pool/main/a/alsa-driver/
lol
so, now that I have those installed, do I need alsa-driver too? or that'll do it
have you ignored the past hour or so? :-)

seems I have to compile those

start up with the computer that is
alsa-lib provides lib*asound2
dmesg should provides clues as to why the drivers weren't loaded automagically

http://piano.juicemedia.tv/junk/alsaprobs <-- I can't make any sense of it, it all seems like mush to me, seems like it can't load/register some important modules? '...' is where I took out parts that didn't seem important, let me know if you want my whole dmesg

if you get a moment, can you take a look at http://piano.juicemedia.tv/junk/alsaprobs <-- I can't make any sense of it, it all seems like mush to me, seems like it can't load/register some important modules? '...' is where I took out parts that didn't seem important

ah, thanks, ok, take a look at http://piano.juicemedia.tv/junk/alsaprobs

an ubuntu one, latest in edgy -- 2.6.17-10-generic
and which alsa version?
are you compiling against the correct linux-headers-$(uname -r) ?

I believe it's 1.0.13
yes
and what do you mean by compiling agains the correct kernel version?
dpkg -l linux-headers-$(uname -r) |grep ^ii
it returned: ii  linux-headers-2.6.17-10-generic 2.6.17-10.33   Linux kernel headers for version 2.6.17 on x86/x86_64
and what parameters did you pass to configure?

to my understanding I compiled the drivers with module-assistant, so whatever it passes I'd assume
unload all the alsa modules, then only modprobe the one you need
then pastebin the error spew and dmesg|tail
ok, how would I unload them all, just look at that file, and unload all those?
yes
well, already I can't sudo modprobe -r snd_seq_device, but sudo lsof /dev/dsp* /dev/snd/* returns no output
sudo modprobe -r $(lsmod |grep ^snd |awk '{print $1}' |sort -r)
I got FATAL: Module snd_timer is in use
purge the alsa-modules-* package that was generated by module-assistant
then what
run the compile and install by hand
would the package be alsa-modules-2.6.17-10-generic?
the version seems strange, but sure
should I purge alsa-driver too?
there's no alsa-driver\* binary package, why?

dpkg -l alsa-driver\*|grep ^ii
yea... it seems I checkinstalled it at one point
ii  alsa-driver    1.0.13-1       Package created with checkinstall 1.6.0
uhh...checkinstall?!
yes, please do remove alsa-driver, then.
it appears so
so remove alsa-modules-2.6.17-10-generic, alsa-driver, and alsa-oss too?
only the first two.
ok, now what
now untar alsa-driver-1.0.13.tar.bz2 afresh, and use the correct parameters to pass to configure
no idea, what's your sound card?
should I put it in /usr/src ?
no
hda-intel
./configure --with-cards=hda-intel --with-oss=yes --with-sequencer=yes --with-debug=full --with-kernel=/lib/modules/$(uname -r)/build && make && sudo make install-modules && sudo depmod -e
oooohhh I remember what you told me to do last time, you told me to get the feisty of alsa-source and compile it with m-a
what about --prefix=/usr
no need
the only thing that's bad is that this isn't going to build a deb :(
ok, what now
brb in 5 min
reboot

well, see, when you installed that alsa-driver made with checkinstall, it SCREWED what Debian [&Ubuntu]  do for infrastructure. Yet another reason checkinstalled packages are BAD.
so. apt-get --reinstall install linux-sound-base alsa-base
in the future, don't stab yourself in the face and ask us to clean up, thanks! :-)
will do ;)
no... still didn't unmute automatically, should I revert back to the alsa-base in edgy? (1.0.11)
didn't you do that with --reinstall?
well, you had me a few days ago install the feisty alsa-base which was 1.0.13
so should I install the edgy version again?
don't use checkinstall. Use the existing packaging infrastructure for mplayer.
but then it'll screw up my packages and such, I think it wants to install a crap load of libraries installed already from edgy, like libavccodecs
no, you're not listening. Use the infrastructure, not the package.
what do you mean?
wouldn't that be make install?
no.
each Debian package has packaging infrastructure. Use it.

apt-get source mplayer
then use the existing debian/
adjust the files as per necessary
